description.narrative:
Insatsen avser programstöd under perioden 2014 - 2015 till tre av Världshälsoorganisationens (WHO) forskningsprogram: Alliance for Health Policy and Systems Research (AHPSR), Special Programme of Research, Development and Research Training in Human Reproduction (HRP) och Special Programme for Research and Training in Tropical Diseases (TDR). Programmet AHPSR kommer under avtalsperioden att fortsatt stärka forskning om hälsosystem och policies som bidrar till att fattiga länder kan nyttja sina resurser för hälsosektorn på ett så effektivt som möjligt. HRP:s inriktning för den kommande två-årsperioden innefattar forskning om ungdomars sexuella och reproduktiva hälsa och förbättrad mödravård under såväl graviditeten som efter förlossning. TDR:s aktiviteter kommer under avtalsperioden att ha tyngdpunkten på forskning om hinder för effektivt genomförande av befintliga kontrollprogram för olika infektionssjukdomar såsom malaria, tuberkulos och olika tarmparasiter.
Sida har lång erfarenhet, sedan mitten av 1970-talet av stöd till forskning i form av såväl speciella fristående forskningsprogram och forskningsprojekt hanterade av WHO. Erfarenheterna visar att organisationen har förmåga att engagera ledande forskare på global nivå för fattigdomsrelaterade hälsofrågor och att i synnerhet de fristående programmen förmår anpassa sig till förändringar i omvärlden och att inta ledande roll inom den globala forskningsagendan.

Sida supports WHO in its efforts to strengthen the knowledge base for the development of normative functions of the WHO and for coordinating, supporting and influencing global efforts to combat a portfolio of major diseases and conditions of the poor and disadvantaged, with a focus on preventing and controlling communicable diseases and improving sexual and reproductive health.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: All three programmes have produced results in line with their results frameworks. Among many achievements during the agreement period 2014 - 2015 some are high-lighted below.
AHPSR: Following the 2014 external review of the AHPSR (report published in December 2014), 2015 was a year of analysis and preparation of the strategic analysis (finalised in March 2015). One systematic review that has received much attention is "Promoting access to health care services for Syrian refugees", which led to a number of actions by the Lebanon Ministry of Public Health, as well as by international agencies.
HRP: In 2015 the estimates of maternal mortality during the period 1990–2015 were published, both as a paper in The Lancet and as a full interagency report. It was estimated that 303 000 maternal deaths will occur in 2015 and there has been a 44% decline in the maternal mortality ratio since 1990; still falling short of the MDG goal.
TDR: TDR supported the development of a platform for testing Ebola treatments in West Africa led by the University of Oxford. This included clinical trials of putative treatments. Two drugs were tested: brincidofovir in Liberia (study terminated due to lack of cases and manufacturer withdrawal); and TKM-Ebola in Sierra Leone (study reached the futility endpoint) – both submitted for publication.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
